awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase II:  Occupancy Estimation and Energy Savings with True Presence Sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will extend to a number of applications, including smart buildings, home automation, and security. The development of this new technology for efficient indoor sensing, and development of new algorithms for occupancy sensing and counting techniques, will have immediate implications in the building automation and home construction industries, where improved occupancy sensing is necessary to achieve the promise of Smart Buildings that adjust environmental conditions such as lighting and air conditioning automatically to suit the needs of the occupants. Implementing this false-alarm free technology will realize millions of dollars in cost savings from reduced energy use. Such energy savings would impact the US energy independence while helping to cut greenhouse gas emissions. In addition to "smart building"/energy efficiency applications there are also significant opportunities to apply these highly-reliable and difficult-to-defeat sensors to facility security, military, law-enforcement/correctional facilities and in-home care monitoring. This project represents Broadening Participation: As a woman-owned minority business in an underrepresented geographical location (Hawaii), the success of Adnoviv will bring opportunity for graduate students through our relationship with the University of Hawaii and encourage young girls to enter Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) related fields.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase II project will result in a revolutionary advance in occupancy sensing for smart buildings and energy-use reduction by providing a low-cost sensor capable of real human presence detection and occupant count and eliminating the issues that have limited the utility of occupancy sensors in many applications. The feasibility of using radio frequency Doppler radar to detect human cardiopulmonary activity and estimate number of occupants using a low power system-on-chip (SoC) platform will be demonstrated. In particular, reliable occupant detection without false alarms, and occupant count estimation will be investigated to further enhance energy savings potential, especially in conjunction with heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) loads. The significant commercial potential of such True Presence Occupancy Detection Sensors in energy-saving applications will be demonstrated in partnership with one of the largest building automation companies in the world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase II project developed True Presence Occupancy Detection Sensors (TruePODS) for indoor spaces. TruePODS employ Doppler radar technology to detect true human presence, occupant count, and vital signs, using a low-power system-on-chip platform and a set of novel algorithms. These low-cost, high-efficiency occupancy sensors integrate the capabilities of sensing, processing and communications in a single device, thus providing the key to realizing small, low-cost, and power-efficient wireless sensor units for Smart Buildings to produce accurate data for tracking by reducing the energy consumption and tracking space utilization, which form a solid basis for important economic and energy decisions. These features have the potential for wide spread use in smart buildings where the ubiquitous collection of subject specific data can be powerful tool in energy efficiency and building sustainability research.

The broader impact of this project includes significant commercial potential for smart building/energy efficiency applications. Societal impact includes improved building energy efficiency resulting in potential annual energy savings of 16 quadrillion Btu (quads), electricity savings of 1100 billion kWh, cost savings of $96 billion, and a CO2 emission reduction equivalent to removing 160 million cars from the road. Energy efficient buildings typically also provide higher levels of occupant comfort, improving productivity.

Enhanced scientific and technological understanding includes development of new algorithms for accurately detecting occupancy/vacancy algorithms, time-frequency-based occupant count algorithms, signal separation from multiple sources, and subject identification. TruePODS will play a key role in the future of big data energy optimization and the emergence of new paradigms in commercial building energy strategies like per-occupant energy analysis.

A device was developed, tested, validated, and deployed. An online data service platform was developed that the sensor could connect to, such that customers could access data in near-real-time. A custom test setup and protocol were developed to enable reproducible measurement of coverage area. A patent has been granted on the algorithm used for occupancy/vacancy sensing. In one implementation, data from the TruePODS sensor was used to adjust HVAC schedules, resulting in savings of approximately $20,000/year in energy spending.

Multiple algorithms were developed to detect occupant count from a single sensor.  Two novel wavelet-based methods were published, which can detect the number of stationary occupants in a room, and an algorithm was developed to determine whether occupants are entering or leaving a room. An algorithm was developed to combine these two approaches to provide constant and accurate room-level occupant count from a single sensor. Multiple patents have resulted from this work. 

Advances have been made in accurately measuring occupant vital signs at any position in a room, and an algorithm has been developed to determine vital signs of multiple occupants at the same time.

TruePODS sensors can provide space usage patterns to enable space to be managed according to actual usage. They can connect to Building Management Systems to control lighting, HVAC, and plug loads based on occupancy status. They can track and verify the number of occupants for occupancy limits. They can enable ventilation to be controlled based on occupant count and activity. They can be used in demand response systems, enabling utilities to shed additional load in unoccupied space. They can track vital signs to provide early detection of health issues. 

The sensors have been implemented in multiple locations. In one, data from TruePODS sensors was used to adjust HVAC schedules resulting in $20,000 annual savings for just one floor of one building. In another implementation, occupancy was differentiated from an empty room over 93% of the time in a 3.4 m x 8.5 m conference room with a single sensor in both wall and ceiling-mounted configurations. Occupancy was successfully detected while an occupant was under the table, visibly blocked from the sensor, a scenario where infrared, ultrasound, and video-based occupancy sensors would fail. Heart and respiratory rates were detected in all seats in the conference room with a single ceiling-mounted sensor.
